title: How to Make a Sewing Kit in a Mason Jar

steps.headline: Get a mason jar with a 2-part lid.
steps.description: They are sometimes sold as "canning jars." Instead of being solid, the lid is composed of 2 parts: a metal ring and a flat disk. The size of the jar does not matter. A smaller jar would be easier to carry, but a larger jar will hold more. You can re-use an old jar instead of buying it from the craft store. Make sure that you clean it first, and that you remove any old labels. If you want to get a small jar, consider getting one of those jelly jars with the molded/decorated sides. It will lend your kit a cute, chic look.

steps.headline: Take the lid apart.
steps.description: Unscrew the jar, then remove the ring. The disk will either come away with the ring, then fall down, or it will stay stuck to the jar. If the disk is stuck to the jar, simply pry it off with your fingernail or a knife.

steps.headline: Paint the outer ring, if desired.
steps.description: Wipe the outer ring down with rubbing alcohol. Take it to a well-ventilated area and set it down on a sheet of newspaper. Shake the can of spray paint, hold it 8 to 10 inches (20 to 25 cm) away from the ring, then apply the paint using a sweeping, side-to-side motion. Let the paint dry, about 20 to 30 minutes, then apply a second coat. Let the second coat dry too. You don't need to wipe down the metal ring with rubbing alcohol if you aren't painting it.

steps.headline: Paint the outside of the jar, if desired.
steps.description: Wipe the outside of the jar down with rubbing alcohol first. Paint the jar as desired using spray paint or acrylic craft paint and let it dry. You can even try chalkboard paint for a rustic touch. If you are using chalkboard paint, however, be sure to let it cure in addition to drying. It's not recommended that you paint the inside of the jar. It may give you a smoother finish, but the items inside the jar may scratch the paint off. Apply acrylic paint using a synthetic taklon brush, not a camelhair brush or a boar bristle brush. It will give you a nicer finish. You don't need to wipe down the jar with rubbing alcohol if you arn't painting it.

steps.headline: Use the inner lid to trace and cut 1 circle from the fabric.
steps.description: Set the flat, inner lid (not the ring part) down on a sheet of cotton fabric, and trace around it using a pen. Cut the circle out just inside the lines that you drew, then set it aside. You will be using this to line the back of your pincushion. You can also use felt or colored cardboard for this circle.

steps.headline: Use the lid to trace and cut a second, larger circle out of fabric.
steps.description: Set the flat, inner lid down on another part of the fabric. This time, trace 1 to 1 ⁄2 inches (2.5 to 3.8 cm) around it, making it bigger. Cut the circle out when you are done. You will be using this circle to make the actual pincushion. Choose a solid or patterned cotton fabric for this.

steps.headline: Sew a gathering stitch around the edges of the larger circle.
steps.description: Sew a straight stitch by hand or on a sewing machine using a ⁄4 to ⁄2 in (0.64 to 1.27 cm) seam allowance; the thread color does not matter. Pull on the thread to gather the circle until it is the same size as the disk. Do not knot or tie the thread off just yet; you may need to adjust the gathering later on. A straight stitch is also referred to as a running stitch. It is where you weave the thread up and down through the fabric. If you are doing this on a sewing machine, use the longest stitch length you can; backstitch when you start sewing, but not when you finish.

steps.headline: Fill the pincushion with polyfill.
steps.description: You can use polyfill or polyester stuffing, but wool batting would be even better. This is because wool contains lanolin, which will help lubricate the pins. Make sure that the pincushion is nice and full.

steps.headline: Tuck the disk into the pincushion and finish the gathering.
steps.description: Tuck the disk part of the lid into the pincushion so that the underside is visible through the hole. Pull on the threads so that the gathering is tight, then knot and cut them off. If you want to, hot glue the gathered edges of the fabric to the underside of the lid.

steps.headline: Hot glue the smaller circle to the back of the lid.
steps.description: Coat the gathered edges of the pincushion with hot glue. Quickly press your smaller fabric circle into the glue before it sets; make sure that the right side of the fabric is facing you. This will not only make the inside of the lid look nicer, but it will also help prevent the gathered edges from peeling. If you want to, you can hot glue the 2 lids together. Line the inside of the ring with hot glue, then fit it over the pincushion. You can also use fabric glue for this step. Let the fabric glue dry before moving on, about 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Add a magnetic strip to the back, if desired.
steps.description: You don't have to do this, but it is a great way to hold all of your pins and needles. Cut a short strip of magnetic tape, and hot glue it to the back of the pin cushion. The exact size of the magnetic strip does not matter, but it needs to be a little smaller than the pincushion. Most magnetic strips have adhesive on the back, but this adhesive is not very strong. It would be best to hot glue the magnet. You can use fabric glue for this step as well. Let it dry completely before moving on.

steps.headline: Fill your kit with basic sewing necessities.
steps.description: This will include things like sewing pins, needles, thread, and scissors. They are the most basic supplies you will need in order to do any type of hand sewing. A thimble, seam ripper, and measuring tape may also come in handy, but they are not absolutely necessary. Expert Answer						Q				When asked, "What are the basic sewing necessities?" Lois Wade																			wikiHow Crafts Expert										Lois Wade has 45 years of experience in crafts including sewing, crochet, needlepoint, cross-stitch, drawing, and paper crafts. She has been contributing to craft articles on wikiHow since 2007. EXPERT ADVICE				DIY and sewing guru, Lois Wade, responded: "It depends on your sewing needs. Of course you'll need a needle and thread and scissors to start, but you can get quite involved if you’re going to do very tailored costumes or work with fabrics that have special handling needs, like voile, knit, leather, or lace."

steps.headline: Keep your items small and compact.
steps.description: Rather than using full-size scissors, go for smaller ones. If you are using a really small jar, consider using embroidery scissors or the kind that fold up. Large spools of thread take up a lot of space, so use bobbins instead; thread multiple bobbins onto a piece of ribbon to keep them together. Some store-bought garments come with spare buttons and closures in tiny, zippered bags. Add these to your kit!

steps.headline: Add some notions.
steps.description: This includes items such as buttons, eyelets, zippers, and other types of closures. Notions are typically sold in packages of 25 to 50, but you don't need to use the entire package in your kit. For example, instead of including all 50 eyelets of hook-and-eye sets, you might just want to use 5 or 6. You also do not need to include every color of button out there. Keep the colors neutral: black and white.

steps.headline: Organize smaller items by packaging them individually.
steps.description: Don't just dump everything into your jar, or you will spend a lot of time trying to find what you need. Sort the notions into pill boxes, miniature mint tins, or tiny glass bottles. You can even buy small, plastic jars or zippered baggies from the beading section of a craft store.

steps.headline: Add fabric and lace trim to give your kit more charm.
steps.description: These items are not absolutely necessary, but they can give your jar a nice touch, especially if you are giving it away as a gift. Wrap some ribbon or lace trim around a wooden spool or cork, and add it to the kit. You can also add in a folded square of fabric or a crochet doily. Keep the fabric scraps small. Something between 6 to 12 inches (15 to 30 cm) square would be ideal.

steps.headline: Do not overcrowd your jar.
steps.description: Remember: less is more. Keep the bulk of your sewing supplies in a cabinet or drawer, and the most important items in your kit. If you overcrowd your jar, the kit will start to look messy. Items are also more likely to get broken, damaged, or tangled.

steps.headline: Cater the kit to your needs.
steps.description: If you find that you do mostly embroidery, then include more embroidery supplies in your kit, such as embroidery needles and thread. If you find that you use your kit mostly for quick repairs, then focus on items that will get the job done quickly, such as fabric glue or safety pins. Focus on the colors that you use in your sewing. If you don't like red, don't own anything red, and never plan on sewing in red, then don't include any red thread, zippers, or buttons.
